news.title: Faintest Hisses from Space Reveal Famous Star's Past Life
news.summary: Astronomers have managed to peer into the past of a nearby star millions of years before its famous explosion, using a telescope in remote outback Australia at a site free from FM radio interference.

news.title: Faintest hisses from space reveal famous exploding star's past life
news.summary: In a neighbouring galaxy only 168,000 light years from Earth, a giant star ended its life in a famous explosion that was seen from Earth in 1987.

news.title: Astronomers peer further into supernova’s past
news.summary: 0 Bookmark Researchers have discovered the unknown past of a star millions of years before its explosion was seen in 1987, after detecting low radio frequencies it emitted.

news.title: Low-Frequency Radio Observations Reveal Past Life of Supernova 1987A
news.summary: Aug 02, 2016 02:04 AM EDT An international team of researchers was able to peer in the past life of the brightest supernova remnant seen from Earth using low-frequency radio observations.

news.title: Low-Frequency Radio Observations Reveal Past Life of Supernova 1987A
news.summary: Aug 02, 2016 02:04 AM EDT An international team of researchers was able to peer in the past life of the brightest supernova remnant seen from Earth using low-frequency radio observations.

news.title: Faintest hisses from space reveal famous star's past life
news.summary: News Hour: Research by an international team including astronomers at the International Centre of Radio Astronomy Research (ICRAR) observing the region at the lowest-ever radio frequencies has helped fine-tune our understanding of stellar explosions.
